channel.title: Digital Garden, again on
channel.description: Recent content in Digital Garden, again on

item.description: What you’re reading here is not a blog, it’s a “digital garden”. It consists of posts like blog, but they can grow, like plants.

Install argocd-autopilot on raspi k3s Create blank git repo e.g. https://github.com/narze/home-cluster Create Github Personal Access Token https://github.com/settings/tokens/new Install argocd-autopilot brew install argocd-autopilot 1 2 3 4 export GIT_TOKEN=your_github_pat export GIT_REPO=https://github.
https://www.shopify.com/careers/how-we-hire Positions Can I apply for more than one job? Yes. Please limit to 3 applications within a 30-day period.

item.title: 100 Days of Writing
item.description: I’ve been thinking of this challenge while I was doing #100DaysOfCode. As I want to be a better writer/blogger as well.

item.title: Amazon SES Setup
item.description: Create new domain identity to be able to send emails. Create new test email identity to be able to receive test emails.

item.title: asdf - The Ultimate Version Manager
item.description: Due to the differences of the dependencies of your projects (and others on GitHub.) Now it’s pretty normal to have multiple versions of programming languages like Python, Node.

item.title: Cold Brew Coffee savings
item.description: I forget the exact number all the time, so I’ll put it here. Coffee beans (250g) : 120 THB / bag 1 bag of coffee can do around 3 batches of cold brew 1 batch of cold brew = 4 shots of coffee (no milk) so it will be 10 THB / cup

item.title: Colemak Mod-DHm
item.description: After 7 years of switching to Colemak keyboard layout, I decided to move on to a new layout. I have seen Mod-DH for quite a while.

item.title: Data Oriented Programming
item.description: Summary A story about adopting Data-Oriented Programming paradigm and it’s 4 principles which reduce complexity compared to Object-Oriented Programming (OOP).

item.title: Debug-less development
item.description: Debug-less Development Are you using console.log all the time when you create websites? Are you adding breakpoints in every if-else blocks in IDE?

item.title: Digital Detox
item.description: Every once in a while, I slipped into the world full of distractions, named the Internet. Like everyone does, I take hours viewing Youtube videos, scroll through Facebook posts, reading Tweets, and so on.

item.title: Generating an optimized Thai keyboard layout
item.description: I built a new Thai keyboard layout called Manoonchai Toward a more useful Thai keyboard layout All of the Thai keyboard layouts are created in the typewriter era.

item.title: ghq
item.description: In all of my 3 Macs, I store all of my code within ~/Code to make it persistent and easy to use across the machines.

item.title: Hit that snooze, but once
item.description: I’m not a morning person, and I will over-sleep all the time if I don’t set the alarm. Moreover, like many people does, I set up a lot of snoozes too, and the result is that I will always wake up, hit the snooze button, then go back to sleep.

item.title: How I git
item.description: Inspired by this post, this is my take on how I use git. Command line! Using Sourcetree is so 2010 üòú Some people said to me that they can choose only the files they want to stage and commit.

item.title: How I sleep
item.description: I am a sleepy person, on weekends I sleep for 9-12 hours. Though my deep sleep rate is more than average (30% of sleeping time).

item.title: How I tmux
item.description: I’m a fan of tmux. However, I hardly use tmux alone without these tools. .tmux I good tmux config for starter.

item.title: Imperfect Productivity Routine
item.description: It’s hard to keep tracking and doing productive activities, especially when you want to do many things every day. I tried and failed so many times.

item.title: Maintaining Momentum
item.description: The key to keep doing what you want to do, is to do it less, but frequently. It is what I do in 100 Days of Writing.

item.title: My Coding Workflow (2020)
item.description: Rule of Thumb Almost everything I do start with command line interface. Now I use Kitty with Zsh. Here are my Dotfiles Since I have 3 macOS machines (2 Macbooks & 1 Hackintosh desktop), I sync my non-dotfiles with Syncthing and have a backup NAS at home.

item.title: My Dotfiles (2020)
item.description: I keep updating my Dotfiles to sync all of my Mac machines. Dotfiles are configuration files on the system which can be edit and share as a plain text.

item.title: My User Manual (2020)
item.description: I was inspired from Fostering psychological safety with a personal user manual. This is the manual about how you can interact or work with me.

item.description: Obsidian is the latest note taking app I’m using. After moving from Evernote and Notion, I ended up with Obsidian which is decent in many ways.

item.title: Personal OKRs
item.description: New year’s resolutions are not working for me. I used to set goals every year, and then I quit doing them within 2-3 months.

item.title: Pomodoro Workflow
item.description: Pomodoro technique is one of the productivity method I use all the time. It’s easy but very effective. I use this technique whenever I’m working, both in and out of office.

item.title: Reasons you should write tests
item.description: 1. You don’t want your user to be your tester The least happy way to test is to let your users test it.

item.title: Rust for Rubyist
item.description: I’m learning basic Rust. As a veteran Rubyist with OOP skill, Rust is like another world to me. So I’ll try to list the key differences and terminalogies in each language side by side.

item.title: Second Brain
item.description: Second Brain A term coined by Tiago Forte. It’s about capturing everything in a system to reduce information overload. He also created PARA Method.

item.title: Simplicity is Complicated
item.description: I’ve heard people say that they want to make something like “Social network for X”, “WhatsApp, but for Y”, or “Blockchain to solve Z”.

item.title: TailwindCSS
item.description: TailwindCSS is my favorite CSS framework right now. But for common elements like buttons or input forms I use DaisyUI as a component framework which extends TailwindCSS to get the job done.

item.title: The only 2 kills those matter
item.description: Master these 2 meta-skills which will lead to learning everything faster. Input Output Just like Internet, the more bandwidth, the better it is.

item.title: Typing Guide
item.description: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1L-P68VDSGlpLM5A9tfRvWFohaR2NzPbkUT0ok34rsFU/edit Practice regularly, take breaks Have good posture “Typing is 99% Muscle Memory” Type before going to bed, have a regular sleep cycle Accuracy First Rhythm Go faster on easy words, slower on hard words Slow down on any words longer than 7 letters or shorter than 3 Read one word ahead Read entire words, not single characters Advanced tricks Use right thumb to press n,m,b (h,k,v an Colemak DH) and sometimes comma Control + Backspace to correct wrong words Improve your reading speed Notice weakness and fix it Alternating between focusing on speed and accuracy

item.title: Typing Practice Drills (2020)
item.description: These are my typing practice drills. I tried to do it every day, 20-30 minutes per day. Common words I like typing on 10ff it’s easy to use and I can use custom CSS to force me to look a word ahead

item.title: Use Git LFS to manage large files in Git repository
item.description: I tried pushing a large file to GitHub and it gave the warning that I should use Git LFS to upload large files.
